Posts.Content: Hi I had my DIEP flap reconstruction two weeks ago.  Although it was a bigger surgery than the mastectomy , so far its been ok.  You will spend longer in hospital and you feel a little uncomfortable for a while after but I'm now fine with the odd paracetamol..  The actual reconstruction I have had done looks amazing so far!!   Hope this helps but if you want to know anything else let me know.   Maria x
Posts.Title: Anyone had a DIEP Flap reconstruction?

Posts.Content: Hi   I had 4 drains in post op, - 2 in my tummy and two in my new breast.  You also have a catheter for the first couple of days, which means you don't really notice the drains at first.  I had 3 drains and the catheter taken out after a couple of days, and the last one in tummy taken out a day or two later.  Whilst in hospital it was quite bent over when I was out of bed, its a bit odd but it certainly helps, just picture yourself as an old woman.  You also need to sleep with pillows under your knees and you can't sleep on your back.  I have been using lots of pillows to support me and have actually got used to sleeping in that position.  The biggest thing to remember is, if you want to move ie get out of bed, you have to pull your knees up first - then its not too bad.  I live in Northampton but went to Stoke Manderville for my op as they have an amazing surgeon there. The surgery takes quite a while (6-8 hours) but you're asleep so of course you don't notice.  Its 2 weeks today since my op. I can move about pretty much standing straight, no pillows under my knees any more, you can't bend down or reach up easily but its not a problem, not really any pain,- my arm aches a bit but easing up, I have excercises to do for it.  You will get tired easily and you have to move about slower than usual. Much better at this stage than I thought I would be so fingers crossed it will keep going the same way. I see my consultant this week. Good luck   Maria
Posts.Title: Anyone had a DIEP Flap reconstruction?

Posts.Content: Hi all I have been on Taxoxifen for about 8 months now and am having quite a few problems with hot flushes/night sweats.  I am being woken up every two hours during the night and I really want to be able to sleep.  My oncologist has put me on Venlalic 37.5mg but with they don't really make much difference.  Does anyone have any suggestions on what to take instead, I've still got years to go! Thanks   Maria
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen, hot flushes and night sweats.

Posts.Content: Thanks for all the great advice, I know I shouldn't be moaning about something as petty as sleepless nights but it does wear you out after a while.  I was off the Tamoxifen for 2 weeks prior to my reconstruction and it was bliss being able to sleep properly for a few days.  I was looking forward to the end of the course - only 4 years to go -but now my oncologist has said that I will probably be one it for a lot longer.  Hey ho - isn't Cancer fun!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Thanks so much for the message, it means a lot!  And a big hug is always a good thing. Maria x
Posts.Title: LCIS

Posts.Content: Hi all Unfortunalely this is a side effect of tax.  I had 3 rounds of this and have managed to keep my nails.  I know this is a bit late but might be helpfull to anyone else.  Before I had my first tax my bcn suggested that I paint my nails with a really dark varnish - black if you are brave enough.  Apparently its light that makes it worse.  Then during my treatment the nurses gave me two bowls of ice water to put my hands in - its not very pleasant but other than a bit of mild discomforate my nails have been fine. Hope this helps Maria x
